moves.1. e4 e5 2. f4 Qh4+ 3. g3 Qf6 4. f5 d6 5: I begin a full frontal attack. This was white's first mistake. The key square in a few turns is g3.
moves.15. Ke2: Now the key square becomes g3. White's rook is mine.
moves.17. Qxh1: The end result of that little bout.
moves.20. Kxe3 Bg6: Moving my bishop to a safe square
moves.21. Nxe5: White gains the smallest of advantages here; the queen is put in a good position, but it doesn't last long.
moves.25. Nd2: White seems to intend to bring the other knight out into play.
moves.25... Rhe8 26. Rf1: White also intends to get the rook into play; perhaps he intends to do Rxf7+ on the next turn, but my bishop guards that pawn, so it would result in a loss of material for him.
moves.26... Kd6+ 27. Kf2: White moves out of check. I think in this case, it would have been better to do Kd4 so as not to trap the rook.
moves.27... Rad8: Moving my other rook into play
moves.28. Rd1 h5 29. Nf3+: White obviously is trying to regain control of the board.
moves.30. Bd3: White makes another mistake. Instead of this move, he should have done Be2. Apparently, he forgot about my bishop.
moves.31. b4+: Rather than taking the bait and losing his rook, White instead tries to force my hand.
moves.34. Kg3 Rxd2: I take the knight because my rook is protected by the king.
moves.35. Rc1+: White doesn't want to exchange rooks
moves.35... Rc2: I interpose, trying to get rid of White's rook
moves.37... Re4: Trying to get White to exchange rooks
moves.41. Re1: Not sure why White did this.
moves.43. Ke5 Re2+: Now White basically has no choice but to exchange.
moves.45... Rxh5: I take White's pawn, effectively protecting mine, as well.
moves.46. Kg6 Kb3: This effectively kills both of White's remaining pawns. No matter which one he moves, the other one dies, and the remaining one would only meet death upon encountering my rank of Black pawns on row 7.
moves.47. b5: Taking a chance to be able to promote it (futile)
moves.47... Bd3+: Both pawns are effectively dead. White does get my Rook, but defeat is unavoidable.
moves.49. Kxg5 Kxa3: At this point, it was also inevitable that one or more of my pawns would be promoted, because the king couldn't get close enough to capture one before it became a Queen.
moves.50. Kf5 c5: Intending to promote my pawns. White resigns.
